last_replies.com: Don't buy SAPIs and only buy ESAPIs after you've done a torque and tap test or you get them from someone reputable. I got a pair of Rev E ESAPIs a couple of years back for $450. If you look around or go to milsurp stores, you should be able to find ESAPIs for roughly that much. The gas system gets a lot of hate, but mine has always functioned flawlessly.
Although, I did buy a repro gas piston and modify it to expel gasses a little earlier and I widened the clearance between the piston and the cylinder wall on the front half of the piston. Say you have to flee a disaster/warzone on foot with only a pack due to roads being shut down or gas becoming unavailable. What guns do you bring?

For me it's a Glock 34 and a Crosman 1377.

> Only carry pistols. Need to conceal weapons from authority/military/blue helmets looking for troublemakers and from thieves looking for lootdrop people to stalk back to their campsite, need to look normal in crowds and slip through chaotic checkpoints, and also need to be ultralight. Can carry duplicates as backups.

> Glock 34 excellent defensive pistol, adequate offensive weapon at short range, can easily strike human targets at 100 yards, cheap and lightweight ammo that can be carried in bulk and found anywhere, can kill big game animals at 50 yards as well as a bow. Leader in long term reliability.

> Crosman air pistol lets me silently forage small game, pellets are 7X cheaper and lighter than .22 ammo, lifetime supply fits in pocket. Long sight radius means high accuracy with no tricks like red dot, silent without $800 NFA device. Allows me to survive in woods for as long as needed.

I wouldn't carry any rifles of any kind unless I could maintain access to a vehicle.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56056178
theres nothing wrong with removing half the mass of a bolt carrier. plenty of companies have done it

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: absolutely doable. you could get the law tactical bolt carrier, swap out the springs for lighter ones (or shorten them yourself), add a threaded bolt handle and a slotted upper. it would work with zero spring pressure and be entirely safe, but I'd rather have some spring pressure holding the bolt carrier forward .

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56055804
Just buy a Kali Key and one of those stripped bufferless bolt carriers.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56055804
Honestly it probably wouldn't even be that hard. As you said, using a barrel with no gas port drilled is already 90% of the way there. Add a side charging upper and carrier, remove the buffer spring and buffer, and that's basically all you need to do.
With a side charger you'd probably be fine with sawing off the rear of the bolt.
Yeah go for it. I don't see anything particularly difficult or dangerous with this project.

threads.name: Zombie coyote
threads.com:
Well, I just had the most horrifying hunting experience of my life.

I’ve been out hunting coyote this year since the start of November. This is the first one I’ve shot, ever. I hunted them last year with no success. I shot this guy broadside at about 70yds using a red light on an 18” 5.56 AR with Frontier 223 (55gr Hornady SP). Perfect shot, best I could tell. Yote dropped, didn’t get up but kept breathing and rolling its head around. I wait a couple minutes, and although I didn’t want to shoot again (I’m in the sticks but still have neighbors), I shot him again because I didn’t want him to suffer.

But he’s still breathing. Another couple minutes, I’m feeling pretty bad at this point. Shot him again. Both of these shots are as he’s down on his side, the bullet is traveling through his entire chest cavity and possibly into his neck.

Still breathing. I shoot him a fourth time, amazed at his will to live but a bit despondent. Still fucking breathing after the fourth shot, I grab my 300 Blackout with subsonics. I verify on my phone that I know where to shoot to hit the brain , and walk out to the coyote. I shot him 11 times in succession with subsonic 300 blackout at point blank range in the head. He would not stop breathing, and even rolled his head around. At this point I’m in shock, distraught that this animal won’t die. I ended up shooting him one more time in the side of the head at the base of the ear, and he finally stopped breathing.

I’ve hunted deer and turkey and I’ve never seen anything like this. Every deer I’ve ever shot was a double lung, several double lung + heart. Every turkey has been a quick kill severing the neck. I know coyotes are tough but I don’t know he survived that long. I’m going to skin him tomorrow and take a close look at what was hit. Was it nerves? How did he continue to breathe?

Sorry for the blogpost but holy cow that was rough

last_replies.com:
It can make sense for the marines to have more rocket artillery than regular artillery so they can better hit landing boats, ships, troop concentrations, support other islands, etc.. Ships won't be able to just sit 100KM out and send in the troops. They will have to expose themselves to land based fires from cheap munitions. Could get expensive.

You could also probably have a whole bunch of MLRS on a bigger island covering the whole thing and all be able to hit one spot at once instead of having to move all the regular artillery around to get in range of a potential landing farther away. Better, faster, concentration of fires, if that makes sense.

Obviously the cost of rockets over artillery is expensive, but it is a lot cheaper than planes and cruise missiles.

The range on some of the rockets is impressive too, maybe they might be able to create an interdependent mutually supporting rocket fire network over an entire island chain, making it even more difficult to disrupt. Also could do area disruptions with assistance from planes, drones, and ships. Basically make it impossible (from a likely attrition perspective) for China to project force away from their mainland.

Could be kind of Kino to watch like 15 different islands with rocket artillery interdict one landing spot on a single island and force the Chinese to take all of them and suffer immense casualties. That was one of the problems in WW2 for Japan. Once an island lost their fighters they were essentially a self-regulating prison camp that was not benefiting the war effort and the soldiers just starved to death without causing the Americans any loss of sleep. The Americans just left them and moved up the island chain.

It could also help the Americans if they want to retake an island since they could saturate a nearby one with rocket artillery and then cheaply bomb the Chinese into paste while not exposing planes and warships.

threads.com:
Previous >>55922136
Finally a new cover edition!

Resource on what these spec terminology mean
https://www.nite-walker.com/post/2019/11/21/specs-for-dummies-101
https://apollogearco.com/blogs/news/night-vision-specs-explained
https://gloomgroup.com/blogs/night-vision-info/night-vision-specifications-understanding-what-they-mean

You shouldn't be chasing for spec values but they do exist and if you wanted to know what "better spec" values are there's a way to know which unit is desirable over another.
Most retailers won't post this info as they build NVDs to order, first come first serve, and depending on their grading scale of high, mid, low tier it may differ from retailers. If a retailer offer a “ready to ship” fully built units they will list the spec values. Hand select is an option from retailers that will try to match to your spec requirements.

Some reputable retailers:
https://www.jrhenterprises.com/
https://nvisionoptics.com/
https://www.customnightvision.com/
https://gooningear.com/
https://blackphasetactical.com/
https://steeleindustries.com/

SNR: signal to noise ratio, the amount of signal the tube can make compared to the noise
EBI: equivalent background information, how much false image appears in the screen through which the actual image has to show, sort of a noise floor of sorts
Halo: How big the circle of bloom is around lights
Photocathode Sensitivity: How sensitive the photocathode is
LP Resolution: Line pair res of the center of the image as measure against a standardized chart

If one spec is shit it negates the rest, if you have a halo of 2.0 it kinda fucks on an EBI of 0.20 if you want to do any kind of shooting and it's all a balance game

The numbers to meet or beat are
EBI under 1, preferably under 0.6 being great, 0.1 is gucci
Halo under 1, anything under 0.7 is awesome
SNR, over 25 anything over 30 is gucci
Photocathode, 1900+ is pretty great, 2500+ is stellar
Resolution of 64+ is good, 72+ is gucci

threads.com:
In the execution video of Yevgeny Nuzhin, he states that he had been hit on the head while walking around Kyiv and woke up in a cellar.

Russia having agents in Kyiv is old news; during the first days of the conflict in February you had people in Kyiv flashing and painting IR beacons for the VKS (Russian Air Force) and artillery. These were likely FSB, or FSB assets. I'll post some of these below.
On the inverse, US Ambassador Michael McFaul recently said Ukraine has sleeper cells in Moscow
https://twitter.com/nytimes/status/1587856053064110080
(around the 19 minute mark)

Yevgeny Nuzhin's case is different, though; Wagner has their own command structure and seems to operate separately from the Russian government; Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov's response to the execution video was "It was not our business", and this definitely seemed to be a personal matter for Wagner.
This would mean that Wagner not only has a dedicated intelligence apparatus, but also has enough agents within Kyiv to successfully find, track, and abduct one man.

Why is this not being discussed? Are Wagner's independent intelligence capabilities known, or have they at least been speculated upon? How strong would their cell in Kyiv need to be to find and abduct Yevgeny Nuzhin? How much of an impact would they play if Russia tries a second strike at Kyiv alongside the Belarusian military?
